Expectation1: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation1: Their teacher invited them to summarize key teachings for a temple session tomorrow.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: I sat cross-legged on my cushion, the evening air cool against my skin as I tried to focus on the sutra before me. My teacher’s words echoed in my mind: “Tomorrow, please share your summary of the Four Noble Truths with the group.” I felt honored, but also anxious—I wanted to do justice to the teachings, to reflect deeply and prepare something meaningful. Yet, my phone buzzed with a reminder: my volunteer shift at the shelter started early in the morning. I knew the others could cover for me if I was a bit late, but I also knew how much the team valued punctuality and reliability. I could almost hear my coordinator’s gentle but firm voice: “We count on you.” The two expectations pressed in on me—one calling me to spiritual depth and responsibility, the other to practical service and dependability. My mind spun with guilt and uncertainty, torn between the quiet of the temple and the bustle of the shelter, wondering how I could possibly honor both commitments without letting someone down.
